awd_titl_txt: Chip-scale classical and quantum nonlinear photonic mixers
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to develop a chip-scale technology for compact and efficient nonlinear classical and quantum photonic mixers while maintaining compatibility with silicon integrated optoelectronics. Proposed research builds on recent accomplishments of slow-light enhanced nonlinearity which is 20x higher than that of conventional silicon nanophotonic waveguides, correlated photon generation via spontaneous four-wave mixing in long chains of low loss coupled silicon microring resonator waveguides, and telecom-band to infrared four-wave mixing conversion in nitride-clad silicon waveguides. Devices will be designed, fabricated and measured which combine electro-optic functionality, materials engineering and lithographic patterning to substantially improve the figures of merit of nonlinear optical frequency conversion applications.  

The intellectual merit is to develop chip-scale devices with orders-of-magnitude improvement in energy efficiency, and reduction in size, weight and cost, compared to fiber-based or crystal-based bulk nonlinear optical systems. Novel scientific insights will emerge from the systematic study of combined electro-optic and nonlinear optical phenomena in both the classical and quantum regime, bridging traditional barriers between those fields. The outcome of this project will be the creation of optoelectronic devices useful for data and free-space communication, chemical and biomolecular spectroscopy, sensing, metrology, cryptography, and quantum photonics.

The broader impacts are to integrate several modern scientific disciplines, to which graduate students will gain valuable exposure and benefit from research collaborations with industry and government laboratories which provide broader perspective and scope for field applications of the novel scientific breakthroughs.

por.por_cntn:
The research in this project was directed towards developing a new class of low-power optical wave-mixing (i.e., nonlinear) devices using silicon photonics as the platform. The principal advantages of using silicon are (i) micro-electronics components alongside the micro-photonics components and (ii) inexpensive, yet precise, fabrication technologies via foundries as long as certain design rules and guidelines are followed. We have designed and characterized novel designs for nonlinear optics and quantum photonics demonstrating both of these aspects.

Traditionally, it has been thought that silicon photonics is unsuitable for nonlinear optics because of materials limitations such as two-photon and free-carrier absorption. But these effects can be mitigated by design, or by the incorporation of ancillary components as part of the device structure. They are also not relevant limitations in certain regimes, such as the low-pump-power regime that is useful for chip-scale quantum photonics, and instead, the optoelectronics capability of silicon presents many advantages not available in fiber- or crystal-based photonics.  

Research in this project has shown a number of record results, e.g., the first silicon photonic room-temperature heralded single photon source, the highest four-wave mixing efficiency in silicon microring resonators at telecommunications wavelengths, the first time a high-Q micro-resonator generating photon pairs has been used with a monitoring electronic-readout diode, the first time a pulse-generating electronic diode has been used to potentially eliminate the need for optical mode-locked pump lasers (thus potentially reducing cost and complexity by many orders of magnitude), etc. We have also shown record performance in thermally-tuned -based optical filters, and demonstrated variable bandwidth and variable center-wavelength operation. We have assembled and operated entanglement-verification apparatus that is likely to become a useful resource for a number of follow-on projects. With these initial building blocks in hand, we can envision a new generation of more advanced micro-optoelectronic circuits which may bring nonlinear optical mixers and quantum light sources from the research laboratory towards real-world applications.

Through this highly-interdisciplinary project, graduate students and post-doctoral researchers have benefited from training and research opportunities. We designed silicon photonic chips using the rules and procedure of a widely-accessible silicon photonic multi-project wafer (MPW) process, which can be adopted by other researchers. Our research outcomes have been published in several journal papers and both contributed and invited talks at major conferences, specialized workshops and many seminars at universities, national laboratories and companies. Opto-electronic devices designed to operate at the intersection of classical and quantum technologies are likely to become very important in the future development of distributed, energy-efficient and beyond-classical information processing computers and networks.
